solution.text:
Electric field due to an electric dipole at points situated at a distance r along its axial line is given as,

Electric field due to an electric dipole at points situated at a distance r along its equatorial plane is is given as,

$$\frac{E_{axial}}{Eequ} = 2$$

Therefore, ratio is 2:1

question.text: The electric charges are distributed in a small volume. The flux of the electric field through a spherical surface of radius 10 cm surrounding the total charge is 20 Vm. The flux over a concentric sphere of radius 20 cm will be

solution.text:
According to Gauss’s law total flux coming out of a closed surface enclosing charge q is given by

$\phi = \oint_{}^{}{\overrightarrow{E}.d\overrightarrow{S}} = \frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}}$

From this expression, it is clear that total flux linked with a closed surface only depends on the enclosed charge and independent of the shape and size of the surface.

$\phi = \oint_{}^{}{\overrightarrow{E}.d\overrightarrow{S}} = \frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}} = 20\ Vm$ given

This $\frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}}$ is constant as long as the enclosed charge is constant

⇒ The flux over a concentric sphere of radius 20 cm = 20Vm

question.text: An infinite number of charges, each of charge 1 μC, are placed on the x−axis with co-ordinates x = 1, 2, 4, 8, ….∞. If a charge of 1C is kept at the origin, then what is the net force acting on 1C charge

solution.text:
The schematic diagram of distribution of charges on x−axis is shown in figure below:

Total force acting on 1C charge is given by

$F = \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\left\lbrack \frac{1 \times 1 \times 10^{- 6}}{(1)^{2}} + \frac{1 \times 1 \times 10^{- 6}}{(2)^{2}} \right.\ $

$\left. \ + \frac{1 \times 1 \times 10^{- 6}}{(4)^{2}} + \frac{1 \times 1 \times 10^{- 6}}{(8)^{2}} + \ ....\infty \right\rbrack$

$= \frac{10^{- 6}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\left( \frac{1}{1} + \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{16} + \frac{1}{64} + \ldots\infty \right) = 9 \times 10^{9} \times 10^{- 6}\ \left( \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{4}} \right)$

$= 9 \times 10^{9} \times 10^{- 6} \times \frac{4}{3} = 9 \times \frac{4}{3} \times 10^{3} = 12000\ N$.

question.text:
A charge Q is divided in two parts Q - q. What is value
of q for maximum force between them?

solution.text:
If r is the distance between q and (𝒬−q), the Coulomb force between them is

$F = \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}.\frac{q(\mathcal{Q -}q)}{r^{2}}$

$$= \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}.\frac{(q\mathcal{Q -}q^{2})}{r^{2}}$$

For F to be maximum dF/dq=0 and 𝒬 and r are

constants,

ie $\frac{d}{dq}\left\lbrack \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\left( q\mathcal{Q -}q^{2} \right) \right\rbrack = 0$

i.e, 𝒬−2q = 0 $\left( as\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}} \neq 0 \right)$

or $\frac{q}{\mathcal{Q}} = \frac{1}{2}$

⇒ $\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ q = \frac{\mathcal{Q}}{2}$

Charge on capacitor plates without the dielectric is
 = CV = (5×10−6F) × 1V = 5 × 10−6C = 5μC The capacitance after the dielectric is introduced is
$C^{'} = \frac{\varepsilon_{0}A}{d - \left( t - \frac{t}{K} \right)} = \frac{\varepsilon_{0}A}{1 - \left( \frac{t - \frac{t}{K}}{ d} \right)} = \frac{C}{1 - \left( \frac{t - \frac{t}{K}}{ d} \right)} = \frac{5\mu F}{1 - \left( \frac{4cm - \frac{4cm}{4}}{6cm\ } \right)} =$

$\frac{5\mu F}{1 - (\frac{4 - 1}{6})} = 10\mu F$ ∴ Charge on capacitor plate now will be
Q′ = C′V = 10μF × 1V = 10μC Additional charge transferred  = Q′ − Q = 10μC − 5μC = 5μC.

question.text: Effective capacitance between points A and B in the figure, shown is

solution.text:
The points C and D will be at same potentials since,$\frac{3}{6} = \frac{4}{8}.$

Therefore, capacitance of 2μF will be unaffected.

So, the equivalent circuit can be shown as

The effective capacitance in upper arm in series, is given by

$C_{1} = \frac{3 \times 6}{3 + 6} = \frac{18}{9} = 2\ \mu F$

The effective capacitance in lower arm in series is given by

$C_{2} = \ \frac{4 \times 8}{4 + 8} = \frac{32}{12} = \frac{8}{3}\mu F$

Hence, the resultant capacitance in parallel is given by

$C = C_{1} + C_{2} = 2 + \frac{8}{3} = \frac{14}{3}\mu F$.

question.text: A network of four capacitors of capacity equal to C1 = C, C1 = 2C, C3 = 3C and C4 = 4C are connected to a battery as shown in the figure. The ratio of the charges on C2 and C4 is

C1, C2 and C3 are in series

Or, $\frac{1}{C^{'}} = \frac{6 + 3 + 2}{6C} = \frac{11}{6C}$ or

$C^{'} = \frac{6C}{11}$

All the capacitors in branch 1 is in series so the charge on each capacitor is $Q^{'} = \frac{6}{11}CV$

Also charge on capacitor C4 is Q = 4CV

$\therefore Ratio = \frac{Q^{'}}{Q} = \frac{6CV}{11 \times 4CV} = \frac{3}{22}$

question.text:
When three identical bulbs of 60 watt, 200 volt rating
are connected in series to a 200 volt supply, the power drawn by them
will be

solution.text:
The resistance of each bulb is

$= \frac{V^{2}}{P} = \frac{(200)^{2}}{60}\Omega$

When three blubs are connected in series their resiutant resistance

$= \frac{3 \times (200)^{2}}{60}$

Thus power drawn by the bulb when connected across 200 V supply

$$P = \frac{V^{2}}{R_{re}} = \frac{(200)^{2}}{3 \times (\frac{200)^{2}}{60}} = 20W$$

question.text: The drift velocity of the electrons in a conductor is v when a current I is flowing in it. If both the radius and current are doubled, then drift velocity will be

solution.text:
Step 1: 

Relation between current and drift velocity   

We know that,

I = neAv

Where, A is the cross-sectional area

n is the no. of electrons.

e is the charge of electrons.

$$\therefore v = \frac{I}{neA}\ = \frac{I}{ne\pi r^{2}}$$

$\Rightarrow v \propto \frac{I}{r^{2}}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots\ldots(1)$

Step-2: New drift velocity 

Let, New drift velocity  = v′,

New radius, r′ = 2r

New current, I′ = 2I

From equation (1)

$\frac{v^{'}}{v} = \frac{\left( \frac{I^{'}}{{r^{'}}^{2}} \right)}{\left( \frac{I}{r2} \right)} = \frac{I^{'}}{I} \times {\left( \frac{r}{r^{'}} \right)}^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \ \frac{v'}{v} = \frac{2I}{I} \times {\left( \frac{r}{2r} \right)}^{2}$

$\therefore\ \ v' = \frac{v}{2}$

$$\therefore\ \ \ New\ drift\ velocity\ is\frac{v}{2}$$

question.text: Two cells of emf E each and internal resistance r1 and r2 are connected in series across a load resistance R. If potential difference across the first cell is zero, then find the relation between R. r1 and r2.

Using Kirchhoff's voltage law:

$V_{AB} = ir_{1} - E = \frac{2Er_{1}}{(R + r_{1} + r_{2})} - E$

For VAB = 0, we get:$\ \frac{2Er_{1}}{(R + r_{1} + r_{2})} - E = 0$

$\Rightarrow \ \frac{2r_{1}}{(R + r_{1} + r_{2})} = 1\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ $

question.text: Two metal wires identical dimensions are connected in series. If σ1 and σ2 are the conductivities of the metal wires respectively, then the effective conductivity of the combination is

solution.text:
As both metal wires are of identical dimensions, so their length and area of cross-section will be same. Let them be l and A respectively. Then the resistance of the first wire is

$R_{1} = \frac{l}{\sigma_{1}A}$ ..… (i)

And that of the second wire is

$R_{2} = \frac{l}{\sigma_{2}A}$ …… (ii)

As they are connected in series, so their effective resistance is

RS = R1 + R2

= $\frac{l}{\sigma_{1}A} + \frac{l}{\sigma_{2}A}$ (using (i) and (ii))

= $\frac{l}{A}\left( \frac{1}{\sigma_{1}} + \frac{1}{\sigma_{2}} \right)$ ….. (iii)

If σeff  is the effective conductivity of the combination, then

$R_{S} = \frac{2l}{\sigma_{eff}A}$ ….(iv)

Equating Equations (iii) and (iv), we get

$\frac{2l}{\sigma_{eff}A} = \frac{l}{A}\left( \frac{1}{\sigma_{1}} + \frac{1}{\sigma_{2}} \right)$

$\frac{2}{\sigma_{eff}} = \frac{\sigma_{2} + \sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}$ OR $\sigma_{eff} = \frac{2\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1} + \sigma_{2}}$ (Using (iv))

question.text: A charge q moves in a region where electric field and magnetic field both exist, then force on it is

solution.text:
The force experienced by a changed particle moving in space where electric and magnetic field exists is called Lorentz force. When a charged particle carrying charge q is subjected to an electric field of strength E⃗, it experiences a force given by $\overrightarrow{F_{e}}$ = q E⃗ whose direction is same as E⃗ or opposite of E⃗ depending on the nature of charge, positive or negative. If a charged particle is moving in a magnetic field of strength B⃗ with a velocity v⃗ it experiences a force given by $\overrightarrow{F_{m}}$ = q (v⃗ x B⃗).  The direction of this force is in the direction of v⃗ x B⃗ ie. Perpendicular to the plane containing v⃗ and B⃗ and is directed as given by right hand screw rule. Due to both the electric and magnetic fields, the total force experienced by the charge q is given by

Given by

$\overrightarrow{F} = \overrightarrow{F_{e}}$ +$\overrightarrow{F_{m}}$ = q E⃗ + q (v⃗ x B⃗)

Since, the currents in the three wires are flowing in same direction so, the wire B will experience a force of attraction due to both wires A and C,

So, $F_{AB} = \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\ .\frac{2i_{A}i_{B}}{d} = \ \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\ .\frac{2 \times 1 \times 2}{d}$

$= \frac{4\mu_{0}}{4\pi d}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(i)$

and $F_{CB} = \ \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\ .\frac{2i_{B}i_{C}}{d} = \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi} \times \frac{2 \times 2 \times 3}{d}$

$= \frac{12\mu_{0}}{4\pi d}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(ii)$

As seen from Eqs. (i) and (ii) FCB > FAB hence, the net force of attraction will be directed towards wire C.

question.text: An electron and a proton of equal linear momentum enter in the direction perpendicular to uniform magnetic field. If the radii of their circular paths be re and rp respectively, then $\frac{r_{e}}{r_{p}},$ is equal to me= mass of electron, mp= mass of proton.

$r_{e} = \frac{m_{e}v_{e}}{qB}$

For a proton the radius of circular path is

$r_{p} = \frac{m_{p}v_{p}}{qB}$

Hence, $\frac{r_{e}}{r_{p}} = 1$.

question.text: A charged particle (charge q) is moving in a circle of radius R with uniform speed v. The associated magnetic moment μ is given by

solution.text:
As revolving charge is equivalent to a current, so

$I = q\ f = q \times \frac{\omega}{2\pi}$

But $\omega = \frac{v}{R}$

Where R is radius of circle and v is uniform speed of charged particle.

Therefore, $I = \frac{qv}{2\pi R}$

Now, magnetic moment associated with charged particle is given by

μ = IA = I × πR2

or $\mu = \frac{qv}{2\pi R}\ \times \pi R^{2} = \frac{1}{2}\ qvR$.

question.text: The electric current in a circular coil of 2 turns produces a magnetic induction B1 at its centre. The coil is unwound and is rewound into a circular coil of 5 turns and the same current produces a magnetic induction B2  at its centre. The ratio of $\frac{B_{2\ \ }}{B_{1}}$ is

. $B = \frac{n\mu_{0}l}{2R}$

question.text: A wire A, bent in the shape of an arc of circle, carrying a current of 2A and having radius 2 cm and another wire B, also bent in the shape of arc of a circle, carrying a current of 3A and having radius of 4 cm, are placed as shown in the figure. solution.text:
Given: IA = 2A; RA = 2cm, θA = $2\pi - \frac{\pi}{2} = \frac{3\pi}{2}$

IB = 3A; RB = 4cm, θB = $2\pi - \frac{\pi}{2} = \frac{5\pi}{3}$

Using magnetic field, $B = \frac{\mu_{0}I\theta}{4\pi R}$

$\frac{B_{A}}{B_{B}} = \frac{I_{A}}{I_{B}} \times \frac{\theta_{A}R_{B}}{\theta_{B}R_{A}} = \frac{2 \times \frac{3\pi}{2} \times 4}{3 \times \frac{5\pi}{3} \times 2} = \frac{6}{5}$.

question.text:

$$\Rightarrow \frac{6}{5} = \sqrt{\frac{9}{4}}\frac{q_{2}}{q_{1}}$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{q_{2}}{q_{1}} = \frac{3}{2} \times \frac{5}{6} = \frac{5}{4}$$

question.text: A bar magnet of magnetic moment M is placed at right angles to a magnetic induction B. If a force F is experienced by each pole of the magnet, the length of the magnet will be

solution.text:
Given: Magnetic moment or bar magnet = M

Magnetic field  = B

Force experienced by each pole = F

As we know, torque experienced by bar magnet kept in magnetic field B of magnetic moment m is given by,

τ = M⃗ × B⃗

 = MBsinθ

Since, the magnetic moment is at the right angle with a magnetic field, so  θ = 90∘

As, sin90∘ = 1

So, τ = MB     (1)

Also, torque experienced by bar magnet is given by,

τ = r⃗ × F⃗

As, θ = 90∘,

So, τ = rF   

As, r = L, where L is the length of bar magnet.

Therefore,  τ = LF    (2)

From (1) and (2) we get,

$L = \frac{MB}{F}$

A thin rectangular magnet suspended freely has a period of oscillation equal to T. Now it is broken into two equal halves (each having half of the original length) and one piece is made to oscillate freely in the same field. If its period of oscillation is T’, the ratio T’/T

solution.text:
When magnet is divided into two equal parts, the magnetic dipole moment

M′= pole strength$\times \frac{l}{2} = \frac{M}{2}$

(pole strength remains same)

Also, the mass of magnet becomes half, ie,

$m^{'} = \frac{m}{2}$

Moment of inertia of magnet

$\ I = \frac{ml^{2}}{12}$

New moment of inertia

$\ I^{'} = \frac{1}{12}\left( \frac{m}{2} \right)\left( \frac{l}{2} \right)^{2} = \frac{ml^{2}}{12 \times 8}$

$\therefore\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ I^{'} = \frac{I}{8}$

Now, $T = 2\pi\sqrt{\left( \frac{I}{MB_{H}} \right)}$

$T^{'} = 2\pi\sqrt{\left( \frac{I^{'}}{M^{'}B_{H}} \right)}\ = 2\pi\sqrt{\left( \frac{I/8}{MB_{H}/2\ } \right)\ }\ $

$\therefore\ \ \ T^{'} = \frac{T}{2} \Longrightarrow \frac{T^{'}}{T} = \frac{1}{2}$.

question.text:

kg/m<sup>–2</sup> around any diameter and is carrying current to produce

When a uniform magnetic field of 4T is applied along the vertical, it
starts rotating, around its horizontal diameter. The angular speed the
coil acquires after rotating by 60° will be

solution.text:
Given,

Moment of inertia of circular coil, I = 0.8 kgm2

Moment of inertia of circular coil, M = 20 Am2

Rotational kinetic energy of circular coil, KE = $\frac{1}{2}I\omega^{2}$

Here, ω = angular speed of coil

Potential energy of bar magnet = –MB cosφ

From energy conservation,

$\frac{1}{2}I\omega^{2}$= Um – Uf = –MB cos600 –(–MB)

⇒ $\frac{MB}{2}$= $\frac{1}{2}I\omega^{2}$

⇒ $\frac{20\ \times 4}{2} = \frac{1}{2}(0.8)\omega^{2}$

⇒ 100 = ω2 ⇒  ω = 10 rad

For paramagnetic material. According to curies law

$\chi\ \propto \ \frac{1}{T}$

For two temperatures T1 and T2

 χ1T1 = χ2T2

But $\ \ \chi\ = \ \frac{1}{B}$

∴ $\frac{I_{1}}{B_{1}}T_{1} = \frac{I_{2}}{B_{2}}T_{2}$

⇒ $\frac{6}{0.4} \times \ 4 = \frac{I_{2}}{0.3} \times \ 24\ \Rightarrow \ I_{2} = \frac{0.3}{0.4} = 0.75\ A/m$

question.text:
Whenever a magnet is moved either towards or away from a
conducting coil, an emf is induced, the magnitude of which is
independent of

d.text: The strength of the magnetic field
The speed with which the magnet is moved
The number of turns is the coil

solution.text:
Whenever a magnet is moved either towards or away from a conducting coil, the magnetic flux linked with the coil changes and therefore, an emf is induced in the coil. The magnitude of induced emf

$e = - N\ \frac{d\phi}{dt}$

$e = - N\ \frac{d(BA)}{dt}$

Time interval dt, depends on the speed with which the magnet is moved.

Therefore, the induced emf is independent of the resistance of the coil.

$\Rightarrow \ \ \ X_{L}^{2} = \frac{R^{2}}{(0.6)^{2}} - R^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \ \ \ X_{L}^{2} = \frac{R^{2} \times 0.64}{0.36}$

$\therefore\ \ \ \ {\ X}_{L} = \frac{0.8\ R}{0.6} = \frac{4R}{3}$ …(i)

IInd case

Therefore, circuit is purely resistive, ie, it contains only resistance. This is the condition of resonance in which

 XL = XC

$\therefore\ \ \ \ \ X_{C} = \frac{4R}{3} = \frac{4}{3}\ \times \frac{110}{3} = \frac{440}{9}\Omega$ [From Eq. (i)]

$\frac{1}{2\pi fC} = \frac{440}{9}\ \Omega$

$C = \frac{9}{2 \times 3.14 \times 60 \times 440}$

 = 54 μF.

solution.text:
Maxwell's equations are:

3. $\nabla \times E = - \frac{dB}{dt}$

4. ∇×B=$\mu_{0}J + \frac{1}{c^{2}}\ \frac{dE}{dt}$

so, considering the last eqn. written,

∇ × B = μ0J is the Ampere's eqn.

question.text: A parallel plate capacitor is charged by a battery as shown in the figure. If two circular amperian loops x and y are drawn then $\oint_{}^{}{\overrightarrow{B}.\overrightarrow{dI}}$ will be zero along

solution.text:
A = $\frac{A}{2}$

Separation between the plates = d

Constant current = i

Now, the electric field between plates of the capacitor

$E = \frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}A}$

Now, the flux through the area

$\phi E = \frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}A} \times \frac{A}{2}$

$\phi E = \frac{q}{2\varepsilon_{0}}$

Now, the displacement current is

$I_{d} = \varepsilon_{0} \times \frac{d\phi E}{dt}$

$I_{d} = \varepsilon_{0} \times \frac{d\left( \frac{q}{2\varepsilon_{0}} \right)}{dt}$

$I_{d} = \frac{1}{2}\left( \frac{dq}{dt} \right)$

$I_{d} = \frac{i}{2}$

Hence, the displacement current is $\frac{i}{2}$

$$= \ 1\ \mathring{\mathrm{A}}$$

Therefore, the given electromagnetic radiation belongs to the X-ray region of electromagnetic spectrum.

Momentum of a photon

Momentum over unit area

$= \frac{E}{Ac} = \frac{I}{c}\lbrack I = \frac{E}{A} for\ \ \ wave\rbrack$ Since surface is non reflecting, final momentum of photon = 0, change in momentum = cI​

So, force per unit area = Pressure of radiation = $\frac{I}{c}$

∴ $\overrightarrow{B} = \frac{E_{0}}{C}( - \widehat{x} + \widehat{y})$sin (kz – ωt).

Relation between electric field E0 and magnetic field B0 of an electromagnetic wave is given by

$e = \frac{E_{0}}{B_{0}}$ (Here, c = speed of light)

question.text:
When light waves suffer reflection at the interface
between air and glass, the change of phase of the reflected wave is
equal to

solution.text: When light waves are incident on the interface between air and glass, then for the first ray there is no phase change on reflection from such an interface. question.text: When light travels from glass to air, the incident angle is θ1 and the refracted angle is θ2. The true relation is

question.text:
A light moves from denser to rarer medium. Which of the
following is correct?

solution.text: When a ray of light moves from one medium to other, its velocity changes. This change depends on refractive index of the medium. Light travels from denser to rarer medium, ie., from medium of higher refractive index to lower refractive index. So, in second (rarer) medium, its velocity increases.

question.text:
Why is refractive index in a transparent medium greater
than one?

d.text: Because the speed of light in vacuum is medium

Because the speed of light in vacuum is always greater than speed in
a transparent medium
Frequency of wave changes when it crosses medium

solution.text:
Absolute refractive index is defined as the ratio of speed of light in free space to that in a given medium

$ie,\ \mu = \frac{c}{v}$

For a given light, denser is the medium, lesser will be the speed of light and so greater will be the refractive index, eg, as vglass > vwater, μg < μw. As speed of light in vacuum is always greater than speed in a transparent medium, so the refractive index in a transparent medium is greater than one.

question.text:

solution.text:
When light enters water from vacuum, then wavelength of light

$\lambda' = \frac{\lambda}{\mu}$

For water, μ > 1

So,
λ′ < λ

Hence, wavelength of light decreases, when light enter to water from vacuum.

An equiconvex lens is cut into two halves along (i) XOX’ and (ii) YOY’ as shown in the figure. Let f, f’, f’’ be the focal lengths of the complete lens, of each half in case (i), and of each half in case (ii), m respectively.

Choose the correct statement from the following

solution.text:
Since the lens is equiconvex, the radius of curvature of each half is same, say R. We know from Lens maker’s formula

$\ \frac{1}{f}$ = ($\mu - 1)\ \left( \frac{1}{R_{1}} - \frac{1}{R_{2}} \right)$

(considering the lens to be placed in air).

Here R1 = R R2 = −R by convection

∴ $\frac{1}{f}$ = (μ − 1) $\frac{2}{R}$ ⇒ (μ − 1) $\frac{1}{R} = \ \frac{1}{2f}$ …(i)

If we cut the lens along XOX’ then the two halves of the lens will be having the same radii of curvature and so, focal length f’ = f

But when we cut it along YOY’ then, we will have R1 = R but R2 = ∞

∴ $\frac{1}{f''}$ = (μ − 1) $\left( \frac{1}{R} - \frac{1}{\infty} \right)$ = (μ − 1) $\frac{1}{R} - \frac{1}{2f}$ ⇒ f’’ = 2f.

question.text:

question.text: A beam of light consisting of red, green and blue colours is incident on a right angled prism. The refractive index of the material of the prism for the above red, green and blue wavelengths are 1.39, 1.44 and 1.47 respectively. The prism will

d.text: not separate the three colours at all
separate the red colour part from the green and blue colours
separate the blue colour part from the red and green colours
separate all the three colours from one another

solution.text:
As beam of light is incident normally on the face AB of the right angled prism. ABC, so no refraction occurs at face AB and it passes straight and strikes the face AC at an angle of incidence, I = 450.

For total reflection to take place at face AC, I > ic or sini > sinic

Where ic is the critical angle.

But as here i= 450 and sin ic = $\frac{1}{\mu}$

∴ sin 450 >$\ \frac{1}{\mu}$ or $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ > $\frac{1}{\mu}$ or μ >$\sqrt{2}$ = 1.414

As μred (=1.39) < μ (=1.414), so only red colour will be transmitted through face AC while green and blue colours will suffer total internal reflection. So the prism will separate red colour from the green and blue colours as shown in the following figure.

question.text: The angle of a prism is A. One of its refracting surfaces is silvered. Light rays falling at an angle of incidence 2A on the first surface returns back through the same path after suffering reflection at the silvered surface. The refractive index μ of the prism is

solution.text:
On reflection from the silvered surface, the incident ray will retrace its path, if it falls normally on the surface.

By geometry, r = A

Applying Snell’s law at surface PQ,

sini = μsinr

μ = $\frac{\sin i}{\sin r}$ = $\frac{\sin{2A}}{\sin A}$ = 2cos A.

question.text: An object moving at a speed of 5 m/s towards a concave mirror of focal length f = 1m is at a distance of 9 m. The average speed of the image is

solution.text:
According to mirror formula

$\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{v} + \frac{1}{u}$

Here u =  − 9 m and f =  − 1 m

$\frac{1}{( - 1)} - \frac{1}{( - 9)} = \frac{1}{v}$

$\Rightarrow v = \ - \frac{9}{8}m$

As the object moves at a constant speed of 5 m/s after 1 s the new position of image is

u′=  − 9 m + 5 m=  − 4 m

$\therefore\frac{1}{( - 1)} - \frac{1}{( - 4)} = \frac{1}{v'}$

$\Rightarrow v' = \ - \frac{4}{3}m$

The shift in the position of image in 1 s is

$v - v'\ = \ - \frac{9}{8} + \frac{4}{3} = \frac{1}{5}$

∴ Average speed of image $= \frac{\frac{1}{5}m}{s}$

question.text:
An object is gradually moving away from the focal point

solution.text:
Using mirror formula, magnification is given by

$m = \frac{f}{u - f} = \frac{- 1}{1 - \frac{u}{f}}$

At focus magnification is ∞

And at u = 2f, magnification is 1.

Hence graph (c) correctly depicts ‘m’ versus distance of object ‘x’ graph.

${\ \ \ \ \mu}_{1} = \frac{3}{2}(Glass)$

$V_{1} = \frac{C_{1}}{{\ \ \ \ \mu}_{1}} = \frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{\frac{3}{2}} = 2 \times 10^{8}\ m/s\ $

d = 90cm = 0.9m 

$t_{1} = \frac{d}{V_{1}} = 0.9m/2 \times 10^{8}m/s$

t1 = 0.45 × 108 s

    μ2 = 4/3(water)

$V_{2} = \frac{C_{1}}{{{\ \ \ \ \mu}_{2}}_{\ }} = \frac{3 \times 10^{8}m/s}{4/3} = 2.25 \times 10^{8}m/s$

d = 90cm = 0.9m

$t_{2} = \frac{d}{V_{2}} = \frac{0.9}{0.25 \times 10^{8}m/s}$

t2 = 0.4 × 10−8s

t1 − t2 = 0.45 × 10−8s − 0.40 × 10−8 = 0.05 × 10−8s

t1 − t2 = 5 × 10−10s

question.text:
The rectilinear propagation of light in a medium is due
to

solution.text:
Newton considered light as made up of particle called
corpuscles. The corpuscles of light were assumed to be almost point like
particles without any mass. They travel with a tremendously high speed,
so they experience a negligible force of gravity. As a result, the
corpuscles travel in a straight line.

question.text:

light is

solution.text:
According to Newton’s corpuscular theory, speed of light
in a rarer medium (like air) is lesser than that in a denser medium
(like water, glass).

question.text:
Which of the following cannot be explained on the basis of wave nature of light?

(i) Polarization

(ii) Optical activity

(iii) Photoelectric effect

(iv) Compton effect

solution.text:
Photoelectric effect and Compton effect cannot be
explained on the basis of wave nature of light while polarization and
optical activity can be explained.

question.text:
Which of the phenomenon is not common to sound and light
waves?

solution.text:
Sound waves cannot be polarized as they are
longitudinal. Light waves can be polarized as they are transverse.

question.text: Light waves travel in vacuum along the y – axis. Which of the following may represent the wavefront?

solution.text: As velocity of light is perpendicular to the wavefront, and light is travelling in vacuum along the y − axis, therefore, the wavefront is represented by y = constant.

question.text:

When the point source or linear source of light is at
very large distance, a small portion of spherical or cylindrical
wavefront appears to be plane. Such a wavefront is plane wavefront.

question.text:

Wave theory of light was first proposed by Christiar.
Huygens.

To demonstrate interference, to coherent sources are
required. Sources are called coherent when they emit waves of nearly
equal or equal frequency and a constant phase difference
throughout.

When they have same frequency and a constant phase difference

When they have constant phase difference and different
frequencies

When they have varying phase difference and different
frequencies

solution.text:
Two sources of light are said to be coherent when both
give out light waves of the same frequency and constant phase
difference.

question.text: The diffraction effect can be observed in

solution.text:
The bending of light round the corners of the obstacles
or the aperture is called diffraction. It is a characteristic of wave
motion. Since light and sound both travel as waves, hence the phenomenon

question.text:
The main difference between the phenomena of
interference and diffraction is that

d.text:
Diffraction is caused by reflected waves from a source whereas
interference is caused due to refraction of waves from a source

Diffraction is due to interaction of waves derived from the same
source, whereas interference is that bending of light from the same
wavefront

Diffraction is due to interaction of light from wavefront, whereas
the interference is the interaction of two waves derived from the same
source

Diffraction is due to interaction of light from the same wavefront
whereas interference is the interaction of waves from two isolated
sources

solution.text:
In interference, we use two sources while in
diffraction, we use light from two points of the same wave front.

When unpolarized beam of light of intensity
I<sub>0</sub> is incident on two polarizers in contact, the angle
between the axes of two polarizers being 30° then the intensity of the
light finally emerging from the combination is

solution.text: $I = \frac{I_{0}}{2}\cos^{2}\theta = \frac{I_{0}}{2}\cos^{2}30^{0} = \frac{I_{0}}{2}\left( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right)^{2} = \frac{{3I}_{0}}{8}$

question.text:
A beam of light of wavelength 600 nm from a distance
source falls on a single slit 1.00 mm wide and the resulting diffraction
pattern is observed on a screen 2 m away. The distance between the first
dark fringes on either side of the central bright fringe is

solution.text:
Condition for obtaining mth order minima is asinθ = mλ

Thus for obtaining first diffraction minima,

asinθ = λ

$\Longrightarrow sin\theta = \frac{600 \times 10^{- 9}m}{10^{- 3}m} \approx tan\theta = \frac{y}{D}$

 ⇒ y = 1.2 mm

Thus distance between fringes on either side = 2 × y = 2.4 mm.

question.text: A plane wavefront (λ=6×10−7m) falls on a slit 0.4 mm wide. A convex lens of focal length 0.8m placed behind the slit focusses the light on a screen. What is the linear diameter of second maximum

solution.text:
For secondary maxima $d\sin\theta = \frac{5\lambda}{2}$

$\Rightarrow d\theta = d.\frac{x}{D( \approx f)} = \frac{5\lambda}{2}$

$\Rightarrow 2x = \frac{5\lambda f}{d} = \frac{5 \times 0.8 \times 6 \times 10^{- 7}}{4 \times 10^{- 4}} = 6 \times 10^{- 3}m = 6mm$.

question.text: Light of wavelength 2 × 10−3 m falls on a slit of width 4 × 10−3 m. The angular dispersion of the central maximum will be

solution.text:
Angular dispersion of central maximum=angular dispersion of 1st minimum (=2θ)

From $\sin{\theta = \frac{1\lambda}{a} = \frac{2 \times 10^{- 3}}{4 \times 10^{- 3}} = \frac{1}{2}}$

θ = 30∘

∴ 2θ = 2 × 30∘ = 60∘.

question.text: In Young’s double slit experiment, one of the slit is wider than other, so that amplitude of the light from one slit is double of that from other slit. If Im be the maximum intensity, the resultant intensity I when they interfere at phase difference ϕ is given by

solution.text:
Let A1 = A0, Then A2 = 2A0

Intensity I ∝ A2

Hence I1 = I0, I2 = 4I0

We have $I = I_{0} + 4I_{0} + 2\sqrt{I_{0} \times 4I_{0}}\cos\phi$

For Imax, cos ϕ = 1

Hence Im = 9I0 or $I_{0} = \frac{I_{m}}{9}$

When phase difference is ϕ then

$$I = I_{0} + 4I_{0} + 2\sqrt{4I_{0}^{2}}\cos\phi$$

 = I0 + 4I0(1+cosϕ)

$= I_{0}\left( 1 + 8\cos^{2}\frac{\phi}{2} \right)\ \ \left\lbrack \because 1 + \cos{\phi = 2\cos^{2}\frac{\phi}{2}} \right\rbrack$

$= \frac{I_{m}}{9}(1 + 8\cos^{2}{\phi/2})$.

question.text: In the given figure, C is middle point of lineS1S2. A monochromatic light of wavelength λ is incident on slits. The ratio of intensity of S3 and S4 is

solution.text:
As S3, Δx = S1S3 − S2S3 = 0

$$\therefore\ \ \phi = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\mathrm{\Delta}x = 0$$

$$\therefore I_{3} = I_{0} + I_{0} + 2\sqrt{I_{0} \times I_{0}}\left( \cos{0{^\circ}} \right)$$

∴ I3 = 4I0

The path difference at S4 is

$\mathrm{\Delta}x^{'} = S_{1}S_{4} - S_{2}S_{4} = \frac{xd}{D}$ $\left( here,\ x = \frac{\lambda D}{2d} \right)$

$= \frac{d}{D} \times \frac{\lambda D}{2d} = \frac{\lambda}{2}$

$\therefore\ \ \phi^{'} = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\frac{\lambda}{2} = \pi$

∴ I4 = I0 + I0 + 2I0cos π = 0

$$\therefore\frac{I_{3}}{I_{4}} = \frac{4I_{0}}{0} = \infty$$

question.text:
A polarizer – analyser set is adjusted such that the
intensity of light coming out of the analyser is just 10% of the
original intensity. Assuming that the polarizer-analyser set does not
absorb any light, the angle by which the analyser need to be rotated
further to reduce the output intensity to be zero, is:

solution.text:
According to question, the intensity of light coming out of the analyser is just 10% of the original intensity (I0).

Using, I = I0 cos2θ

⇒ $\frac{I_{0}}{I}$= I0 cos2θ ⇒ $\frac{1}{10}$ = cos2θ

⇒ cosθ = $\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} = 0.316\ \ \Rightarrow \ \theta\ \approx \ {71.6}^{0}\ $

Therefore, the angle by which the analyser need to be rotated further to reduce the output intensity to be zero.

φ = 900 – θ = 900 – 71.60 = 18.40

question.text:
A system of three polarizers P<sub>1</sub>,
P<sub>2</sub>, P<sub>3</sub> is set up such that the pass axis of
P<sub>3</sub> is crossed with respect to that of P<sub>1</sub>. The pass
axis of P<sub>2</sub> is inclined at 60º to the pass axis of
P<sub>3</sub>. When a beam of unpolarized light of intensity 10 is
incident on P<sub>1</sub>, the intensity of light transmitted by the
three polarizers is I. The ratio (I<sub>0</sub>/I) equals (nearly):

solution.text:
$I = \left( \frac{I_{0}}{2} \right)\cos^{2}30^{0}\cos^{2}60^{0}$

$= \frac{I_{0}}{2}\ \times \ \frac{3}{4} \times \ \frac{1}{4}$

∴ $\frac{I_{0}}{I} = \frac{32}{3} = 10.67$.

question.text: The work function for tungsten and sodium are 4.5 eV and 2.3 eV respectively. If the threshold wavelength λ for sodium is 5460 Å, the value of λ for tungsten is

Work function,$\ W_{0} = \frac{hc}{\lambda_{0}},$

$so\ W \propto \frac{1}{\lambda},\ $where λ is threshold wavelength.

$Or\ \frac{W_{N}}{W_{t}} = \frac{\lambda_{t}}{\lambda_{N}}$

$so\lambda_{t} = \frac{{\lambda_{N}W}_{N}}{W_{t}} = \frac{5460 \times 2.3}{4.5} = 2790.66\ $ Angstrom nearly 2791 Angstrom.

0.6 × 10−18J = 0.6 × 10−18J $ = \frac{0.6 \times 10^{- 18}J}{1.6 \times \frac{10^{- 19}J}{eV}} = 3.75eV$

question.text:
When a monochromatic point source of light is at a

solution.text:
The cut-off voltage or stopping potential measure maximum kinetic energy of the electron. It depends on the frequency of incident light whereas the current depends on the number of photons incident. Hence, cut-off voltage will be 0.5 V. Now by inverse square law,

$$i \propto I \propto \frac{1}{d^{2}}$$

$12 \propto \frac{1}{(0.2)^{2}}\ \ or\ I \propto \frac{1}{(0.4)^{2}}$

$\therefore\ \ \ \ \frac{I}{12} = \frac{(0.2)^{2}}{(0.4)^{2}} = \frac{1}{4}$

or $I = \frac{12}{4} = 3mA$

question.text: A source S1 is producing, 1015 photons per second of wavelength 5000$\dot{\ A}$. Another source S2 is producing 1.02 x 1015 photons per second of wavelength 5100 Ȧ. Then, (power of S2) / (power of S1) is equal to

= $\frac{{(1.02\ x\ 10}^{15}\ photons/s)\ x\ (5000\ \dot{A)}}{{(10}^{15\ }photons/s)\ x\ (5100\dot{A)}}$ =$\ \frac{51}{51}$ = 1

Let ϕ0 be the work function of the surface of the material. Then,

According to Einstein’s photoelectric equation, the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons in the first case is

Kmax1 = $\frac{hc}{\lambda}$  − ϕ0

and that in the second case is

Kmax2 = $\frac{hc}{\frac{\lambda}{2}}$  − ϕ0 = $\frac{2hc}{\lambda}$  − ϕ0

But Kmax2 = 3Kmax1 (given)

∴ $\frac{2hc}{\lambda}$  − ϕ0 = 3 $\left( \frac{hc}{\lambda} - \phi_{0} \right)$

$\frac{2hc}{\lambda} - \phi_{0} = \frac{3hc}{\lambda} - {3\phi}_{0}$

3ϕ0  − ϕ0 $= \frac{3hc}{\lambda} -$ $\frac{2hc}{\lambda}$

  2ϕ0 = $\frac{hc}{\lambda}$ or ϕ0 = $\frac{hc}{2\lambda}$.

question.text:
When the energy of the incident radiation is increased
by 20%, the kinetic energy of the photoelectrons emitted from a metal
surface increased from 0.5 eV to 0.8 eV. The work function of the metal
is

solution.text:
According to Einstein’s photoelectric equation.

The kinetic energy of emitted photoelectrons is K = hυ  −  ϕ0

Where hυ is the energy of incident radiation and  ϕ0 is work function of the metal.

As per question.

0.5 eV = hυ − ϕ0 … (i)

0.8 eV = 1.2 hυ - ϕ0 … (ii)

On solving eqns. (i) and (ii), we get

ϕ0 = 1.0 eV

question.text: Particle A of mass mA = $\frac{m}{2}$ moving along the x-axis with velocity v0 collides elastically with another particle B at rest having mass mB = $\frac{m}{3}$. If both particles move along the x-axis after the collision, the charge ∆λ in de-Broglie wavelength of particle before collision is:

solution.text:
$\frac{m}{2} \times V_{0} + \frac{m}{3} \times (0) = \frac{m}{2}V_{A} + \frac{m}{2}V_{B}$

$= \frac{V_{0}}{2} = \frac{V_{A}}{2} = \frac{V_{B}}{2}$ ….. (i)

Since collision is elastic 

e = 1 = $\frac{V_{A} - V_{B}}{V_{0}}\ \ \ \Rightarrow \ V_{0} = \ V_{B} - V_{A}\ $ ….. (ii)

On solving equations (i) and (ii) : $V_{A} = \frac{V_{0}}{5}$

Now, de-Broglie wavelength of A before collision

$\lambda_{0} = \frac{h}{m_{A}V_{0}} = \frac{h}{\left( \frac{m}{2} \right)V_{0}}\ \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \lambda_{0} = \ $ $\frac{2h}{mV_{0}}$

Finding de-Broglie wavelength

$\lambda_{f} = \frac{h}{m_{A}V_{0}} = \frac{h}{\frac{m}{2}\ \times \ \frac{V_{0}}{5}}\ \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \lambda_{f} = \frac{10h}{mV_{0}}$

$\therefore\ \mathrm{\Delta}\lambda\ = \lambda_{f} - \lambda_{0} = \frac{10h}{mV_{0}}\ - \frac{2h}{mV_{0}}\ $

$\Rightarrow \ \ \mathrm{\Delta}\lambda\ = \frac{8h}{mV_{0}}\ \ \Rightarrow \ \mathrm{\Delta}\lambda\ = 4\ \times \ \frac{2h}{mV_{0}}\ $

∴ Δλ  = 4λ0 .

question.text:
A particle is moving 5 times as fast as an electron. The
ratio of the de-Broglie wavelength of the particle to that of the
electron is 1.878 × 10<sup>–4</sup>. The mass of the particle is close
to

solution.text:
de-Broglie wavelength

$\lambda = \frac{h}{mv}\ \Rightarrow \ \ \ m = \frac{h}{mv}$ Clearly m ∝ $\frac{1}{\lambda v}$

If λ and v is the wavelength and velocity of electron and ‘λ’ and ‘v’ be the wavelength and velocity of the particle then

$\Rightarrow \frac{m\prime}{m} = \frac{v\lambda}{v\prime\lambda\prime} = \ \frac{1}{5} \times \ \frac{1}{1.878} \times 10^{- 4}\ \ $

⇒ m = 9.7 × 10−28 kg.

question.text: Bohr’s atom model assumes

d.text: The nucleus is of infinite mass and is at rest
Electrons in a quantized orbit will not radiate energy

solution.text:
In 1913, Niels Bohr proposed a model for the hydrogen atom. The Bohr model was based on the following assumptions.

The electron in a hydrogen atom travels around the nucleus in a circular orbit.

The nucleus is of infinite mass and is rest.

Electrons in a quantized orbit will not radiate energy.

Mass of electron remains constant.

question.text: A beam of beryllium nucleus (Z=4) of kinetic energy 5.3 MeV is headed towards the nucleus of gold atom(Z=79). What is the distance of closest approach?

solution.text:
Distance of closest approach$\ d = \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\ \frac{zeZe}{K}$

z = atomic number of incident beam

K = kinetic energy of incident beam

e = electronic charge

Given: z = 4, Z = 79, K = 5.3 Me Ve = 1.6 × 10−19C

$d = \frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times 4 \times 1.6 \times 10^{- 19} \times 79 \times 1.6 \times 10^{- 19}}{5.3 \times 1.6 \times 10^{- 19}} = 8.58 \times 10^{- 14}m$.

question.text: The radius of hydrogen atom in the ground state is 5.3 × 10−11m. after collision with an electron, it is found to have radius of 21.2  × 10−11 m. What is the principal quantum number n of the final state of the atom?

solution.text:
Let us consider the problem:

Find the principle quantum number of the final state of the atom.

$\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} = \frac{n_{1}^{2}}{n_{2}^{2}}$

Implies that

$\frac{1}{n_{2}^{2}} = \frac{5.3 \times 10^{- 11}}{21.2 \times 10^{- 11}}$

Implies that

n22 = 4

Hence, n2 = 2.

question.text: Which state of triply ionised beryllium (Be3+) has the same orbital radius as that of ground state of hydrogen?

solution.text:
Radius of orbit of electron in nth excited state of hydrogen

$r\ = \frac{\varepsilon_{0}h^{2}n^{2}}{{\pi mZe}^{2}}$

$\therefore\ \ \ \ r \propto \frac{n^{2}}{Z}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(i)$

$\therefore\ \ \ \ \frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} = \frac{n_{1}^{2}}{n_{2}^{2}} \times \frac{Z_{2}}{Z_{1}}$

But r1 = r2

So, $n_{2}^{2} = n_{1}^{2}\ \times \frac{Z_{2}}{Z_{1}}$

Here,

n1 = 1(ground state of hydrogen),

 Z1= 1(atomic number of hydrogen),

Z2= 4(atomic number of beryllium)

$\therefore\ \sqrt{n_{2}^{2}}$ = (1)2$\times \frac{4}{1}$

or  n22  = 4

or  n2 = 2

question.text: The angular momentum of an electron in the hydrogen atom is $\frac{3h}{2\pi}$. Here, h is planck’s constant. The kinetic energy of this electron is

question.text:
The total energy of electron in the ground state of
hydrogen atom is -13.6 eV. The potential energy of an electron in the
fifth excited state is
Excitation energy of a hydrogen like atom in its first excitation state is 40.8 eV. Energy needed to remove the electron from the ion in ground state is

solution.text:
The excitation energy in the first excited state is

$E\ = \ {RhcZ}^{2}\left( \frac{1}{1^{2}} - \frac{1}{2^{2}} \right)$ = (13.6 eV) × $Z^{2} \times \frac{3}{4}$

∴ 40.8 = 13.6 × $Z^{2} \times \frac{3}{4}$

⇒    Z = 2

So, the ion in problem is He+. The energy of the ion in the ground state is

$E\ = \ \frac{{RhcZ}^{2}}{1^{2}}\ =$ 13.6 × 4 = 54.4 eV

Hence, 54.4 eV is required to remove the electron from the ion.

question.text: The ionisation potential of hydrogen atom is 13.6 eV. The energy required to remove an electron from the second orbit of hydrogen will be

solution.text:
The potential energy of hydrogen atom

En = $\frac{13.6}{n^{2}}$ eV

So, the potential energy in second orbit is

E2 = − $\frac{13.6}{2^{2}}$ eV

$E_{2}\ = \ - \ \frac{13.6}{4}eV\ = \ - 3.4\ eV$

Now, the energy required to remove an electron from second orbit to infinity is

U = E∞ − E2 [From work-energy theorem and E∞ = 0]

⇒         U = 0 − (−3.4) eV

Or      U = 3.4 eV

Hence, the required energy is 3.4 eV.

question.text: According to Bohr’s theory, the wave number of last line of Balmer series is (R = 1.1 × 107m−1)

question.text: If λ is the wavelength of hydrogen atom from the transition n =3 to n=1, then what is the wavelength for doubly ionised lithium ion for same transition?

solution.text:
For wavelength

$\frac{1}{\lambda} = {RZ}^{2}\left( \frac{1}{n_{1}^{2}} - \frac{1}{n_{2}^{2}} \right)$

Here, transition is same

So, $\ \ \ \ \ \lambda \propto \frac{1}{Z^{2}}$

$\frac{\lambda_{H}}{\lambda_{Li}} = \frac{\left( Z_{Li} \right)^{2}}{\left( Z_{H} \right)^{2}} = \frac{(3)^{1}}{(\ 1)^{2}} = 9$

$\lambda_{Li} = \frac{\lambda_{H}}{\ 9} = \frac{\lambda}{9}$ .

$\frac{v_{L}}{v_{B}} = \frac{27}{5}$.

question.text:
Calculate the highest frequency of the emitted photon in

solution.text:
: frequency of photon for Paschen series is given as$\ \nu = {cZ}^{2}R\left( \frac{1}{9} - \frac{1}{n^{2}} \right)$

n is the orbital quantum number of excited state from where the electron is coming to 3rd state

to get the maximum value of ν take n → ∞

and put Z=1 for hydrogen and R = 1.09 × 107( Rydberg Constant)  with  c = 3 × 108 we get ν = 3.7 × 1014Hz.

question.text:
The total energy of electron in the ground state of
hydrogen atom is -13.6 eV. The kinetic energy of an electron in the
fourth excited state is
Hydrogen atom from excited state comes to the ground state by emitting a photon of wavelength λ. If R is the Rydberg constant, the principal quantum number n of the excited state is

solution.text:
According to Rydberg′s formula 

$\frac{1}{\lambda} = R\left( \frac{1}{n_{f}^{2}} - \frac{1}{n_{i}^{2}} \right)$ Here, nf = 1, n1 = n    $ \therefore\frac{1}{\lambda} = R\left( \frac{1}{1^{2}} - \frac{1}{n^{2}} \right) \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\lambda} = R\left( 1 - \frac{1}{n^{2}} \right)......(i)$ Multiplying equation (i) λλ on both sides. $ 1 = \lambda R\left( 1 - \frac{1}{n^{2}} \right)\ or\ \frac{1}{\lambda R} = 1 - \frac{1}{n^{2}}$ $ or\ \frac{1}{n^{2}} = \frac{1}{\lambda R}or\frac{1}{n^{2}} = \frac{\lambda R - 1}{\lambda R}\ or\ n = \sqrt{\frac{\lambda R}{\lambda R - 1}}$ .

question.text: The wavelength of radiation emitted is λ0 when an electron jumps from the third to second orbit of hydrogen atom. For the electron jumping from the fourth to the second orbit of the hydrogen atom, the wavelength of radiation emitted will be

solution.text:
As in both cases electron came to second orbit, we will consider Balmer series,

Now, for Balmer series, wavelength is given by,

$\frac{1}{\lambda} = R(\frac{1}{2^{2}} - \frac{1}{n^{2}}),n = 3,4,5$

In case1, when n = 3, λ = λ0

$\frac{1}{\lambda_{0}} = R\left( \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{9} \right),n = 3,4,5$

In case2, when n=4, λ is given by

$\frac{1}{\lambda} = R\left( \frac{1}{2^{2}} - \frac{1}{4^{2}} \right)$

$\frac{1}{\lambda} = R\left( \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{16} \right) = \frac{27}{20\lambda_{0}}$

$\lambda = \frac{20\lambda_{0}}{27}$

question.text:
Which of the following transition in Balmer series for
hydrogen will have longest wavelength?

solution.text:
According to the Bohr’s theory the wavelength of radiations emitted from hydrogen atom given by

$\ \frac{1}{\lambda} =$ $R\left\lbrack \frac{1}{n_{1}^{2}} - \frac{1}{n_{2}^{2}} \right\rbrack \Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{n_{1}^{2}n_{2}^{2}}{\left( n_{2}^{2}n_{1}^{2} \right)R}$

For maximum wavelength ifn1 = n,then n2 = n + 1

∴ λ is maximumforn2 = 3 and n1 = 2.

question.text:
Which of the following lines of the H-atom spectrum
belongs to the Balmer series?

solution.text:
The wavelength of different members of Balmer series are given by

$\frac{1}{\lambda}$ $= R_{H}\left\lbrack \frac{1}{2^{2}} - \frac{1}{n_{i}^{2}} \right\rbrack$, where ni= 3,4,5,….

The first member of Balmer series (Hα) corresponds to ni=3.It has maximum energy and hence the longest wavelength. Therefore, wavelength of Hα line (or longest wavelength )

$\frac{1}{\lambda_{1}}$ $= R_{H}\left\lbrack \frac{1}{2^{2}} - \frac{1}{3^{2}} \right\rbrack$

$= 1.097 \times \ 10^{7}\left( \frac{5}{36} \right)$

or        λ1= $\frac{36}{5\ \times \ 1.097\ \times 10^{7}}$ = 6.563 × 10−7 m

$$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ n = \ 6563\ \mathring{\mathrm{A}}$$

The wavelength of the Balmer series limit corresponds to ni = ∞ and has got shortest wavelength.

Therefore , wavelength of Balmer series limit is given by

$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \frac{1}{\lambda_{\infty}}$ =$R_{H}\left\lbrack \frac{1}{2^{2}} - \frac{1}{\infty^{2}} \right\rbrack$ $= 1.097\ \times \ 10^{7}\ \times \ \frac{1}{4}$

or$\ \ \ \lambda_{\infty} = \frac{4}{1.097\ \times 10^{7}}$ =3.646 × 10−7 m

$= 3646\mathring{\mathrm{A}}$

question.text:
In the spectrum of hydrogen, the ratio of the longest
wavelength in the Lyman series to the longest wavelength in the Balmer
series is

solution.text:
The wavelength of a spectral line in the Lyman series is

$\frac{1}{\lambda_{L}}$ = R$\ \left( \frac{l}{1^{2}} - \frac{l}{n^{2}} \right)$, n = 2, 3, 4 ……

And that in the Balmer series is

$\frac{1}{\lambda_{B}}\ = \ R\ \left( \frac{l}{2^{2}} - \frac{l}{n^{2}} \right),\ n\ = \ 3,\ 4,\ 5\ \ \ldots\ldots$

For the longest wavelength in the Lyman series, n = 2

∴ $\frac{1}{\lambda_{L}}$ = R $\left( \frac{l}{1^{2}} - \frac{l}{2^{2}} \right) = R\ \left( \frac{1}{1} - \frac{1}{4} \right) = R\left( \frac{4 - 1}{4} \right) = \ \frac{3R}{4}$ or λL  = $\frac{4}{3R}$

For the longest wavelength in the Balmer series,

n = 3

∴ $\frac{1}{\lambda_{B}}$ = R $\left( \frac{l}{2^{2}} - \frac{l}{3^{2}} \right) = R\ \left( \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{9} \right) = R\left( \frac{9 - 4}{36} \right) = \ \frac{5R}{36}$

or λB  = $\frac{36}{5R}$

Thus, $\frac{\lambda_{L}}{\lambda_{B}}$ = $\frac{\left( \frac{4}{3R} \right)}{\left( \frac{36}{5R} \right)} = \frac{4}{3R} \times \frac{5R}{36} = \frac{5}{27}$

question.text: Hydrogen atom in ground state is excited by a monochromatic radiation of λ = 975 Å . Number of spectral lines in the resulting spectrum emitted will be

solution.text:
Energy of the photon, E = $\frac{hc}{\lambda}$ E = $\frac{6.63\ \times {\ 10}^{- 34}\ \times \ 3\ \times \ 10^{8}}{975\ \times 10^{- 10}}$ J

= $\frac{6.63\ \times \ 10^{- 34} \times \ 3\ \times 10^{8}}{975\ \times \ 10^{- 10} \times 1.6 \times 10^{- 19}}$ eV = 12.75 eV

After absorbing a photon of energy 12.75 eV, the electron will reach to third excited state of energy -0.85 eV, since energy difference corresponding to n = 1 and n = 4 is 12.75 eV.

∴ Number of spectral lines emitted

= $\frac{(n)(n - 1)}{2} = \frac{(4)(4 - 1)}{2} = 6$

question.text:
The wavelength of the first line of Lyman series for
hydrogen atom is equal to that of the second line of Balmer series for a

question.text:
Which of the following particles are constituents of the
nucleus

solution.text:
The conclusion from Rutherford's experiment was that the majority of the mass of an atom is concentrated at its center called the nucleus. The nucleus therefore contains the two heaviest particles present in atom.

The protons and the neutrons are present in the nucleus which are bound together by strong nuclear forces which overcome the magnetic force of repulsion.

The electrons are found in orbitals outside the nucleus.

question.text:
The particles which can be added to the nucleus of an
atom without changing its chemical properties are called

solution.text:
If we add a neutron to the nucleus of an atom then it becomes an isotope of the same element of which the parent atom was. This won't change the chemical properties of the element.

If we add an electron to the nucleus, then it will convert a proton to a neutron. The atomic number will become 1 less and will get converted into an atom of the previous element on the periodic table. This will definitely change the properties.

If we add a proton, then the atomic number will become 1 more and will get converted into an atom of the next element on the periodic table. This will definitely change the properties.

question.text:
In an insulator, the forbidden energy gap between the
valance band and conduction band is of the order of

solution.text:
Forbidden energy gap, also known as band gap refers to the energy difference   (eV) between the top of valence band and the bottom of the conduction band in materials. Current flowing through the materials is due to the electron transfer from the valence band to the conduction band.

Insulators do not conduct electricity because a large amount of energy is needed for the electrons to cross the forbidden energy gap. Moreover the forbidden energy gap is the widest (>5eV) in case of insulators.

Example:  Forbidden energy gap in diamond is nearly 5.5eV.

question.text: In a pn junction

d.text: high potential at n side and low potential at p side
high potential at p side and low potential at n side
p and n both are at same potential

solution.text:
A p-n junction is shown in the figure. On account of difference in concentration of charge carriers in the two sections of p-n junction, the electrons from n-region diffuse through the junction into p-region and the holes from p-region diffuse into n-region.

Since the hole is a vacancy of an electron, when an electron from n region diffuses into the p-region, the electron falls into the vacancy, i.e. it completes the covalent bond. Due to migration of charge carriers across the junction, the n-region of the junction will have its electrons neutralized by holes from the p-region, leaving only ionized donor atoms (positive charges) which are bound and cannot move. Similarly, the p region of the junction will have ionized acceptor atoms (negative charges) which are immobile.

The accumulation of electric charges of opposite polarities in the two regions of the junction gives rise to an electric filed between these regions as if a fictitious battery is connected across the junction with its positive terminal connected to n region and negative terminal connected to p region. Therefore in a p-n junction high potential is at N side and low potential is at P side.

question.text: In forward bias, the width of potential barrier in a p-n junction diode

solution.text: In forward biasing, the conduction across p-n junction takes place due to migrations of majority carriers (i.e. electrons from n-side to p-side and holes from p-side to n-side), hence the size of depletion region decreases.

question.text: Within depletion region of p-n junction diode

d.text: p-side is positive and n-side is negative
p-side is negative and n-side is positive
Both sides are positive or both negative

solution.text:
In a p-n junction diode, electrons in conduction band on n-type side travel across the junction and leave the positively ionized impurity atoms unneutralised. Consequently, there is positively charged region adjacent to the junction in n-type material. On p-type side the electrons which have traversed the boundary recombine with positive holes in the valence

band and form a layer of unneutralised negatively ionised trivalent impurity atoms making a negatively charged region as shown in figure. The region around the junction is called charge depletion region or space charge region. Hence, within the depletion region, p-side is negative and n-side is positive

solution.text: Zener diode is a highly doped p-n junction which is not damaged by high reverse current. It can operate continuously without being damaged in the region of reverse breakdown voltage. In the forward bias, the zener diode acts as ordinary diode. It can be used as voltage regulator.

question.text:
Which of the following option is true for Zener
diode?

d.text: Highly doped (P-N) junction, used in forward biased
Weakly doped (P-N) junction, used in reverse biased
Weakly doped (P-N) junction, used in forward biased
Highly doped (P-N) junction, used in reverse biased

solution.text:
A Zener diode is highly doped and used in reverse
biased

question.text: The main cause of zener breakdown is

d.text: Production of electron-hole pairs due to thermal excitation

solution.text: : The main cause of zener breakdown is high doping.

question.text: The temperature coefficient of a zener mechanism is

solution.text: Zener breakdown occurs in heavily doped p-n junction. The temperature coefficient of the zener mechanism is negative or the breakdown voltage for a particular diode decreases with increasing temperature.

question.text: LED is a p-n junction diode which is

d.text: Either forward biased or reverse biased
Neither forward biased nor reverse biased

solution.text:
When a junction diode is forward biased, energy is
released at the junction due to recombination of electrons and holes. In
the junction diode made of gallium arsenide or indium phosphide the
energy is released in visible region. Such a junction diode is called a
light emitting diode or LED

question.text: An intrinsic semiconductor has a resistivity of 0.50 Ω m at room temperature. Find the intrinsic carrier concentration if the mobilities of electrons and holes are 0.39 m2/volt sec and 0.11 m2/volt sec respectively

solution.text:
σ = e(neue+nhuh) $ \because\sigma = \frac{1}{\rho}$ In intrinsic semi-conductor

ne = nh = n$\frac{1}{\rho} = e \times n(\mu_{e} + \mu_{h})$ $ \frac{1}{0.50} = 1.6 \times 10^{- 19} \times n(0.39 + 0.11)$ $ \frac{1 \times 10^{19}}{0.5 \times 0.5 \times 1.6} = n$ $ \frac{100 \times 10^{19}}{25 \times 1.6} = n$ 1640 × 1019 = n n = 2.5 × 1019/m3

question.text: The contribution in the total current flowing through a semiconductor due to electrons and holes are $\frac{3}{4}$ and $\frac{1}{4}$ respectively. If the drift velocity of electrons is $\frac{5}{2}$ times that of holes at this temperature, then the radio of concentration of electrons and holes is

solution.text:
As we know, current density J = nqv

⇒ je = ne qve

and Jh = nh qvh

$\frac{j_{e}}{J_{h}} = \frac{n_{e}}{n_{h}} \times \frac{v_{e}}{v_{h}}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{\frac{3}{4}}{\frac{1}{4}} = \frac{n_{e}}{n_{h}} \times \frac{5}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{n_{e}}{n_{h}} = \frac{6}{5}$

question.text: A silicon specimen is made into a p-type semiconductor by doping on the average one indium atom per 5 × 107 silicon atoms. If the number density of atoms in the silicon specimen is 5 × 1028 atoms/m3. Then the number of acceptor atoms in silicon will be

solution.text:
Number density of atoms in Si$ = 5 \times 10^{28}\ \frac{atoms}{m^{3}} = 5 \times 10^{22}\ \frac{atoms}{{cm}^{3}}$ Since 1 atom of indium is doped in 5 × 107  silicon atoms,∴ Total number of doped indium atoms

$= \frac{5 \times 10^{22}}{\ 5 \times 10^{7}} = 1 \times 10^{15}\frac{atoms}{{cm}^{3}}$ ∴ Number of acceptor atoms in silicon

$= 1 \times 10^{15}\frac{atoms}{{cm}^{3}}$.

question.text: A diode having potential difference 0.5 V across its junction which does not depend on current, is connected in series with resistance of 20Ω across source. If 0.1 A current passes through resistance then what is the voltage of the source?

solution.text:
The circuit diagram of the given situation is shown. Since, it is a closed mesh, the voltage is

V = V′ + IR

Given, V′ = 0.5 V, I = 0.1 A, R = 20Ω

V = 0.5 + 0.1 × 20

V = 2.5 volt.

question.text: The diode used in the circuit shown in the figure has a constant voltage drop at 0.5 V at all currents and a maximum power rating of 100 milli watts. What should be the value of the resistor R, connected in series with diode for obtaining maximum current?

solution.text:
Voltage drop across diode (VD) = 0.5 V, Maximum power rating of diode (P) = 100 mW = 100 x 10-3 W

And source voltage (Vs) = 1.5 V

The resistance of diode (RD)

$\frac{V_{D}^{2}}{P}\ $= $\frac{(0.5)^{2}}{{100\ \times \ 10}^{- 3}}$ = 2.5 Ω

And current in diode (ID) = $\frac{V_{D}}{R_{D}} = \frac{0.5}{2.5}$ = 0.2 A

Therefore total resistance in circuit (R)

= $\frac{V_{s}}{I_{D}}$ = $\frac{1.5}{0.2} = 7.5\ \Omega$

And the value of the series resistor = Total resistance of the circuit – Resistance of diode

= 7.5 -2.5 = 5 Ω
